raw_text:
Charity single for quake relief
 
 Singers including Sir Cliff Richard and Boy George are recording a charity single to help raise funds for victims of the Asian tsunami.
 
 They hope the song will raise more than £2m for the relief fund. The song, titled Grief Never Grows Old and described as a melancholy ballad, was written by radio DJ Mike Read. Former Boyzone singer Ronan Keating may also take part if a studio can be found close to where he is holidaying in Switzerland. Other music stars being approached include Robin and Barry Gibb of The Bee Gees, jazz sensation Jamie Cullum, Chris Rea and Olivia Newton-John.
 
 Sir Cliff has recorded his vocal part in Barbados, while Boy George has recorded his in New York. Read wrote the song before the Boxing Day tragedy but had thought it was too gloomy to release. Now he plans to have it recorded by a collection of pop stars under the name One World Project. "It's a natural home for it because people kept saying to me, 'it's such a good song', but it's such a sad song," Read said.
 
 He said the song was a slow ballad and would work with around 10 singers, rather than a "sing-along" like the Band Aid 20 single raising money for famine relief in Africa. The backing track has already been recorded and organisers hope it can be finished within the next week to get it into record shops as soon as possible. Read went to the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC), which is co-ordinating the British relief effort, with the idea the day after Boxing Day. "I was totally shocked at the enormity and suddenness of the disaster and in tears on seeing the orphaned children wandering aimlessly in search of their parents," he said. Read said all the funds raised by the record would go to the DEC. "I'd only be pleased in terms of what it meant for sales if it got to number one," he added. The charity welcomed the news of the single and said money raised would help its agencies working in the affected region to rebuild survivors' lives and livelihoods.
llama3.2:1b: Charity singers, including Sir Cliff Richard and Boy George, are recording a song called "Grief Never Grows Old" for quake relief efforts.
The song will raise more than £2m for the relief fund.
Other music stars who may participate include Robin and Barry Gibb of The Bee Gees, Jamie Cullum, Chris Rea, Olivia Newton-John, Ronan Keating, and Guy Martin.
llama3.2:3b: Sir Cliff Richard and Boy George are recording a charity single, Grief Never Grows Old, to raise funds for Asian tsunami victims.
The song was written by radio DJ Mike Read and is described as a melancholy ballad.
Other music stars including Robin and Barry Gibb, Jamie Cullum, Chris Rea, and Olivia Newton-John may also take part.
gemma2:2b: A charity single titled "Grief Never Grows Old" is being recorded by several pop stars, including Sir Cliff Richard, Boy George, and Ronan Keating.
The song was written before the tsunami and will be released under the One World Project name.
The proceeds will go to the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) for their relief efforts in Asia.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Sir Cliff Richard, Boy George, and Ronan Keating are recording a charity song titled Grief Never Grows Old, which will aim to raise more than £2 million for victims of the Asian tsunami.
The song has been recorded in Barbados and New York by Boy George.
The backing track will be completed within the next week, allowing the record to reach record shops as soon as possible.
Read made a pledge that all funds raised would go to the British charity DEC.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Singers including Sir Cliff Richard, Boy George, Ronan Keating, and others are recording a charity single titled "Grief Never Grows Old" to raise £2 million for tsunami victims through One World Project.
The song is described as a melancholy ballad written by radio DJ Mike Read.
They plan to record it with 10 or more pop stars in the next week, similar to Band Aid's Africa song.
It was written after Sir Cliff Richard heard about the Asian tsunami disaster and decided to release it quickly due to its powerful message of sympathy for those affected.
The funds raised will support the DEC's efforts to help survivors rebuild their lives and livelihoods.
qwen2.5:3b: Singers like Sir Cliff Richard, Boy George, and Robin Gibb are recording a charity single titled "Grief Never Grows Old" to raise funds for tsunami relief victims.
The song, written by Mike Read, has already been recorded with backing tracks and hopes to reach record shops within the next week.

Originally intended as a slow ballad suitable for around 10 singers, it was inspired after the Boxing Day tragedy and is now seen as a natural fit for the One World Project due to its melancholic nature.
The money raised will go to the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC), which supports agencies in affected regions helping survivors rebuild their lives and livelihoods.

tinydolphin:1.1b: Summary: British singer-songwriters, including Sir Cliff Richard and Boy George, have come together to release a charity single to raise funds for victims of the tsunami disaster.
The song, titled "Grievous Yet Glorious," is described as a melancholy ballad written by radio DJ Mike Read.
Other music stars involved in the effort include Ronan Keating and Robin Gibb of The Bee Gees, jazz sensation Jamie Cullum, Chris Rea, Olivia Newton-John, and British pop star Robbie Williams.

The song has already been recorded by Read in Barbados and George in New York.
It is described as a melancholy ballad, with the aim of raising more than £2m for the relief fund.
The backing track has been recorded and it is hoped that the single will be finished within the next week to get it into record shops quickly.
All funds raised by the record will go towards the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) which co-ordinates the British relief effort.

The song is a slow ballad and can work with around 10 singers, rather than a "sing-along" like the Band Aid 20 single raising money for famine relief in Africa.
The backing track has already been recorded and organisers hope it can be finished within the next week to get it into record shops as soon as possible.
Read went to the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) with the idea of recording the song on Boxing Day, which was the day after the tsunami disaster in Asia.

Written by DJ Mike Read before the disaster, the melancholy ballad was initially deemed too gloomy for release but is now being recorded by a group of artists under the name One World Project.
Other musicians approached include Ronan Keating, Robin and Barry Gibb, Jamie Cullum, Chris Rea, and Olivia Newton-John.
Sir Cliff and Boy George have recorded their parts remotely, and the backing track is complete.
Read proposed the idea to the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) the day after Boxing Day, deeply moved by the tragedy.
The single is expected to be released quickly, with all proceeds going to the DEC to aid survivors.
stablelm2:1.6b: Singers, including Cliff Richard and George, record a £2m+ charity single for Asian tsunami relief titled "Grief Never Grows Old."

The song was written by Mike Read before the tragedy but rewritten after; it will be recorded by various artists under the One World Project, with all funds raised going to the Disasters Emergency Committee.
Potential participants include Robin and Barry Gibb of The Bee Gees, Jamie Cullum, Chris Rea, and Olivia Newton-John.
Sir Cliff recorded his part in Barbados, while Boy George did so in New York.
The backing track has already been recorded and is hoped to be finished within a week for release in record shops soon.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Popular musicians, including Sir Cliff Richard, Boy George, Ronan Keating, Robin Gibb, Barry Gibb, Jamie Cullum, Chris Rea, and Olivia Newton-John, are collaborating on a charity single titled "Grief Never Grows Old."
The song was penned by radio DJ Mike Read before the Asian tsunami tragedy but deemed too somber for release.
Now, it serves as a fundraiser for victims, with all proceeds going to the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC).
The single aims to raise over £2 million, intended for relief efforts in affected regions.
Read wrote the song as a melancholic ballad, which he believes suits a group of pop stars better than a "sing-along" like Band Aid 20's hit.
The backing track has been recorded, and organizers hope to have the final product in record shops within a week.
The charity praised the initiative, emphasizing that the funds will aid survivors' rebuilding efforts and revitalization of their lives and livelihoods.
